case_name: Dr. Mohammad Saeed v. Custodian of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 456 of 1958 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 10, 1957, of the Rajasthan High Court Jaipur Bench in D. B. Civil Reference No. 17 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 456 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 10, 1957, of the Rajasthan High Court  Jaipur Bench  at Jaipur in D. B. Civil Reference No. 17 of 1956.

facts.text: Petition No. 87 of 1961 was filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: WITH PETITION No. 87 of 1961. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental rights.

facts.text: On April 1, 1950, the Deputy Custodian, Jaipur, declared Dr. Mohammad Saeed, a medical practitioner of Jaipur, an intending evacuee under s. 19 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1950, the Deputy Custodian, Jaipur, made an order in proceedings instituted under s. 19 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance declaring the appellant Dr. Mohammad Saeed a medical practitioner of Jaipur to be an intending evacuee.

facts.text: Notice was directed to be issued to the respondent to show cause why he should be declared an evacuee under s. 2(d)(i) and s. 2(d)(iii) of the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: By the same order a numberice was directed to be issued to the respondent to show cause why he should number be declared to be an evacuee under s. 2 d  i  and s. 2 d  iii  of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Another notice was issued to the appellant under s. 22(b) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, to show cause why his property should be declared evacuee property due to transfer of substantial assets to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: When thereafter the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  Act XXXI of 1950 , came into force ano- ther numberice was issued on the appellant under s. 22 b  of the Act to show cause why his property should number be declared evacuee property on the ground that he had transferred a substantial portion of his assets to Pakistan.

facts.text: On November 16, 1951, the Deputy Custodian, Jaipur held Dr. Mohammad Saeed to be an evacuee under s. 2(d)(iii) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949, and his property to be evacuee property under s. 7 of the Ordinance and s. 22(b) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On November 16, 1951, the Deputy Custodian, Jaipur held Dr. Mohammad Saeed to be an evacuee under s. 2 d  iii  of the Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949. He also held Dr. Mohammad Saeeds property to be evacuee property under s. 7 of the Ordinance and also under s. 22 b  of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950.

facts.text: District Judge, Jaipur, on appeal, set aside the declaration of Dr. Mohammad Saeed as an evacuee under s. 2(d)(iii) and remanded for fresh decision.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the District Judge, Jaipur, set aside this declaration of the appellant as an evacuee under s. 2 d  iii  of the Ordinance and remanded the case for a fresh decision in the light of the observations made by him.

facts.text: District Judge agreed that Dr. Mohammad Saeed transferred substantial assets to Pakistan between November 1947 and September 1948, but set aside order under s. 22(b).

anchor.surface_text: As regards the order under s. 22 b  the learned District Judge agreed with the Deputy Custodian that Dr. Mohammed Saeed had transferred a substantial portion of his assets to Pakistan between November 1947 and September 1948.

facts.text: Custodian of Evacuee Property, Rajasthan, moved Custodian-General for revision of District Judge's order.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian of Evacuee Property, Rajasthan, moved the Custodian-General of Evacuee Property for revision of this order.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian-General made reference under s. 27(2) to Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Custodian-General of Evacuee Property who heard this petition in revision was unable to agree with the District Judges findings on the question as regards the order under s. 22 b  and accordingly made a reference under s. 27 2  of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, to the High Court of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court on May 10, 1957, held that transfer of substantial assets from August 14, 1947 to October 18, 1949 constituted preparation for migration to Pakistan and directed disposal accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention raised on behalf of this appellant that the circumstances as to the transfer of a substantial portion of his assets should relate to an act done by any person, after, he was declared as an intending evacuee. It further held that the fact that Dr. Mohammad Saeed had during the period from August 14, 1947 to October 18, 1949, transferred a substantial portion of his assets in India to Pakistan companystituted under the law a preparation for his migration to Pakistan

facts.text: Deputy Custodian-General on August 10, 1957, held the property of the petitioner to be evacuee property under s. 22(b).

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this direction the Deputy Custodian-General on August 10, 1957, held that the property of the petitioner was rightly declared to be evacuee property under s. 22 b  by the Deputy Custodian.

facts.text: Appeal heard in part on January 23, 1961, adjourned to enable writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: After the appeal was heard in part on January 23, 1961, the hearing was adjourned to enable the appellant to make a writ petition.

facts.text: Petition under Art. 32 filed on February 14, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: A petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution was then filed on February 14, 1961, praying for a writ of certiorari and or mandamus or direction to quash the order made under s. 22 b .

facts.text: Dr. Mohammad Saeed transferred a substantial portion of his assets situated in Jaipur to Pakistan before being declared intending evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: It is numberlonger in dispute that Dr. Mohammad Saeed had, before the order appealed from was made, transferred to Pakistan a substantial portion of his assets situated in Jaipur which is part of the territories to which this Act extends. It is further number in dispute that this transfer was made before he was declared an intending evacuee.

facts.text: Transfers occurred between August 14, 1947, and October 18, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: the period from August 14, 1947 to October 18, 1949, transferred a substantial portion of his assets in India to Pakistan

facts.text: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 (Act XXXI of 1950) came into force after April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: When thereafter the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  Act XXXI of 1950 , came into force

facts.text: Dr. Mohammad Saeed is a medical practitioner of Jaipur.

anchor.surface_text: declaring the appellant Dr. Mohammad Saeed a medical practitioner of Jaipur to be an intending evacuee.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the petition under Art. 32 and upheld the appeal decision.

anchor.surface_text: The petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts. The appeal raises the question of the effect of the application of s. 22 b  of the Act to the facts of the present case.

facts.text: The transfer of substantial assets to Pakistan constitutes circumstances prescribed as constituting preparation for migration under s. 22(b).

anchor.surface_text: Explanation-The following shall be deemed to be some of the circumstances prescribed under clause  b , namely- the transfer to Pakistan by any person referred to in that clause of a substantial portion of his assets situated in any part of the territories to which this Act extends

anchor.surface_text: In the first place it is to be pointed out that a person who transferred assets between the 14th August, 1947, and the 18th October, 1949, and a person who transferred such assets after the 18th October, 1949, cannot properly be companysidered to be similarly circumstanced. It has to be borne in mind that political relations between India and Pakistan were in a fluid and disturbed state immediately after the 14th August, 1947, but the position improved to a companysiderable extent by the 18th October, 1949, which it may be numbericed was the date when the Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949, was made. Persons who had transferred assets between the 14th August, 1947, and the 18th October, 1949, may therefore reasonably have been companysidered by the legislature to form a class distinct in respect of the application of the law to their property from those who transferred assets after the 18th October, 1949.

concepts.interpretation: Classification based on date of transfer valid due to different political context; groups not similarly situated; rational nexus to policy of property treatment

By the same order a numberice was directed to be issued to the respondent to show cause why he should number be declared to be an evacuee under s. 2 d  i  and s. 2 d  iii  of the Ordinance. When thereafter the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  Act XXXI of 1950 , came into force ano- ther numberice was issued on the appellant under s. 22 b  of the Act to show cause why his property should number be declared evacuee property on the ground that he had transferred a substantial portion of his assets to Pakistan.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 22(b), Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950
concepts.unlisted_description: Empowers Custodian to declare property of intending evacuee as evacuee property if circumstances show preparation for migration to Pakistan, e.g., substantial asset transfer to Pakistan

anchor.surface_text: Section 22 b , substituting therein for the words he had done any of the acts specified in sub-clauses and  iii  of clause  e  of s. 2 the words of only cluse 2 e  i , reads thus- If the Custodian is satisfied, after such enquiry as may be prescribed, that the circumstances relating to any person, in respect of whom a declaration has been so made on the ground that after the 14th day of August, 1947, and before the 18th day of October, 1949, he has transferred to Pakistan his assets or any part thereof situated in any part of the territories to which this Act extends are such as may be prescribed as companystituting a preparation for his migration to Pakistan, the Custodian may declare any property situated in the State in which such person has any right or interest to be evacuee property and on the issue of such numberification any property specified in the numberification shall be deemed to be evacuee property which has vested in the Custodian within the meaning of this Act.

issues.text: whether s. 22(b) contravenes Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: that s. 22 b  contravenes Art. 14 of the Constitution has been pressed before us. While however in the grounds as stated in the petition the attack was that discrimination had been made between persons declared as intending evacuee in

issues.text: whether the transfer having been made before the declaration was made is not available for consideration for the purpose of an order under s. 22(b)

anchor.surface_text: The first contention raised on behalf of the appellant was that this transfer having been made before the declaration was made is not available for consideration for the purpose of an order under s. 22 b . The contention is clearly unwarranted.

issues.text: the question of the effect of the application of s. 22(b) of the Act to the facts of the present case

anchor.surface_text: The petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. The appeal raises the question of the effect of the application of s. 22 b  of the Act to the facts of the present case.

issues.text: whether it would be proper for the Custodian to take other circumstances including the later conduct of the intending evacuee to decide whether or not he should declare his property to be evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: It was next urged that in any case it would be proper for the Custodian to take other circumstances including the later conduct of the intending evacuee to decide whether or not he should declare his property to be evacuee property.

arguments.claim: s. 22(b) contravenes Art. 14 due to discrimination between intending evacuees under s.22(b) (pre-Oct 1949 transfers) denied restoration under s.16 and compensation under s.13 DPCRA, and evacuees under s.2(d)(iv) (post-Oct 1949 transfers) who receive those benefits despite similar asset transfers to Pakistan

anchor.surface_text: Art. 14 which Mr. Bishan Narain urged on behalf of the petitioner was that in two matters there was discrimination between an intending evacuee whose property was declared evacuee property under s. 22 b and an evacuee whose property might be declared to be an evacuee property, where the evacuee had done practically the same thing for which another person has been declared as an intending evacuee.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the companyclusion that the circumstances in order that they may be taken into companysideration must also companye into existence after the declarat

arguments.court_reasoning: Transferors before and after 18 Oct 1949 not similarly circumstanced due to differing political contexts; legislature reasonably classified them distinctly; discrimination from omission to extend s.16 and s.13 benefits to intending evacuees, not from s.22(b) itself

arguments.claim: Transfer of assets made before declaration as intending evacuee is not available for consideration under s.22(b)

anchor.surface_text: The first contention raised on behalf of the appellant was that this transfer having been made before the declaration was made is not available for consideration for the purpose of an order under s. 22 b . The contention is clearly unwarranted.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e to be evacuee property whenever the existence of any of the circumstances prescribed as companystituting a preparation for his migrating to Pakistan

arguments.court_reasoning: Normal grammatical construction shows transfer deemed a prescribed circumstance under clause (b) irrespective of whether before or after declaration; only requires circumstances relate to person declared intending evacuee

arguments.claim: Custodian must consider other circumstances including later conduct of intending evacuee before declaring property evacuee property under s.22(b)

anchor.surface_text: It was next urged that in any case it would be proper for the Custodian to take other circumstances including the later conduct of the intending evacuee to decide whether or not he should declare his property to be evacuee property.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to decide if other circumstances can be considered; where prescribed circumstance like substantial transfer exists, declaration is authorized and proper; no basis to say improperly made

arguments.claim: For s.22(b), not only pre-18 Oct 1949 transfer but other circumstances including post-18 Oct 1949 conduct must be considered to determine preparation for migration

anchor.surface_text: As regards the order under s. 22 b the learned District Judge agreed with the Deputy Custodian that Dr. Mohammed Saeed had transferred a substantial portion of his assets to Pakistan between November 1947 and September 1948. Being of opinion however that not only this act of transfer which took place before the 18th day of October, 1949, but other circumstances including the appellants conduct after October 18, 1949, have to be, taken into consideration before action under section 22 b can be taken,

arguments.claim: Transfer of substantial assets to Pakistan between 14 Aug 1947 and 18 Oct 1949 constitutes preparation for migration under s.22(b), justifying declaration of property as evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: It further held that the fact that Dr. Mohammad Saeed had during the period from August 14, 1947 to October 18, 1949, transferred a substantial portion of his assets in India to Pakistan constituted under the law a preparation for his migration to Pakistan and that this justified a declaration by the Custodian of his property situated in Rajasthan

arguments.court_reasoning: Explicitly deemed circumstance under explanation to s.22(b); plain language applies irrespective of timing relative to declaration; facts undisputed

arguments.claim: Persons transferring assets pre-18 Oct 1949 and post-18 Oct 1949 not similarly circumstanced, justifying distinct classification and denial of s.16/s.13 benefits to former

anchor.surface_text: In the first place it is to be pointed out that a person who transferred assets between the 14th August, 1947, and the 18th October, 1949, and a person who transferred such assets after the 18th October, 1949, cannot properly be considered to be similarly circumstanced. It has to be borne in mind that political relations between India and Pakistan were in a fluid and disturbed state immediately after the 14th August, 1947,

arguments.claim: Discrimination between intending evacuees and evacuees arises from legislative omission to extend s.16 and s.13 benefits to intending evacuees, not from s.22(b)

anchor.surface_text: Next it is important to notice that this differenceviz., that one group of persons is entitled to the benefits of the sections mentioned above while another group is not-does not flow directly or necessarily from s. 22 b . What is characterised as discrimination between an evacuee and an intending evacuee is the consequence of the legislatures omission to extend to the intending evacuees the benefits of s. 16 of the 1950 Act and s. 13 of the 1954 Act

arguments.claim: Dr. Saeed's property is evacuee property under s.22(b) as substantial pre-declaration transfer to Pakistan is a prescribed circumstance constituting preparation for migration

anchor.surface_text: On November 16, 1951, the Deputy Custodian, Jaipur held Dr. Mohammad Saeed to be an evacuee under s. 2 d iii of the Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949. He also held Dr. Mohammad Saeeds property to be evacuee property under s. 7 of the Ordinance and also under s. 22 b of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950.

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts of transfer undisputed; constitutes deemed circumstance under s.22(b) explanation

holdings.text: Section 22(b) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 does not contravene Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that it is possible to say therefore that s. 22 b  of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act companytravenes Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transferors of assets before 18 Oct 1949 and after not similarly circumstanced due to differing political conditions post-partition; reasonable classification; alleged discrimination arises from legislative omission in s.16 and s.13 benefits, not from s.22(b) itself

holdings.text: Transfer of substantial assets to Pakistan before declaration as intending evacuee constitutes a prescribed circumstance under s.22(b) Explanation and may be considered for declaring property evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: On a numbermal grammatical companystruction of the words used by the legislature it is abundantly clear that the transfer to Pakistan of a substantial portion of the assets shall be deemed to be one of the circumstances prescribed under clause  b  irrespective of whether the transfer took place before the declaration as intending evacuee was made or after such declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal grammatical construction of s.22(b) and Explanation deems such transfer a prescribed circumstance relating to the person declared intending evacuee under s.2(e)(i); no requirement that circumstance arise after declaration; scheme of legislation supports considering pre-declaration substantial transfers

holdings.text: Where a prescribed circumstance under s.22(b) such as substantial asset transfer to Pakistan exists, Custodian authorised to declare property evacuee property without needing to consider other circumstances

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary for us to companysider whether it is open to the Custodian to companysider such other circumstances. The section however gives a Custodian the authority to declare the property of a person who has been declared an intending evacuee to be evacuee property whenever the existence of any of the circumstances prescribed as companystituting a preparation for his migrating to Pakistan is established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.22(b) empowers declaration upon satisfaction of prescribed circumstances like substantial transfer; presence of such circumstance validates declaration; unnecessary to decide on additional circumstances

holdings.text: Dr. Mohammad Saeed's property rightly declared evacuee property under s.22(b); High Court order upheld

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was right in setting aside the order of the District Judge and in directing the Custodian-General or the Deputy Custodian-General to dispose of the matter in accordance with the views expressed by the High Court that on the facts proved in the case the order made by the Deputy Custodian declaring Dr. Mohammad Saeeds property as evacuee property was right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed substantial pre-declaration transfer to Pakistan is deemed prescribed circumstance constituting preparation for migration; applies s.22(b) directly to facts; lower court errors corrected

holdings.text: Petition under Article 32 dismissed as s.22(b) constitutional and properly applied

anchor.surface_text: The petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from holdings on constitutionality and statutory application
